@jan simonides I definitely don't understand it to the degree that climate scientists do, but I'm about as qualified to make comments about it as Dan Pena is. No one is suggesting that the climate on this planet isn't cyclical, and saying that the planet was warmer 50k  years ago doesn't in any way discredit the current models of climate change, in fact It supports them. The crux of the climate change issue isn't that things are getting way too warm right now, its that we are currently in a natural warming phase of the planet and our emissions may be (most likely are) contributing to the projected peak temperature of the period, as well as the rate at which the temperature is climbing. Dan Pena tells this same story on his Joe Rogan podcast and in much greater detail and when you listen to it, anyone with even a basic understanding of the concepts of climate change, Like I have outlined here, would understand that the scientists were making fun of Dan Pena and he just didn't understand.

Climate is cyclical. The Milankovitch cycles have a lot of influence on the Climate. Some suggest that the cycles induce the Ice Ages when the amount of energy reaching the poles diminishes to such an extent, that the winter ice does not thaw in the summer and builds on top of the previous year's deposits. This then causes a feedback whereby more sunlight is reflected to space, increasing the build up of Ice.

Feedback systems do exist on this planet. There is a feedback from CO2, but what the Climate Alarmists forget (but the real scientists such as William Happer and Richard Lindzen would tell them) that water is the far more important greenhouse gas, sharing many of the same absorption spectra as CO2 and that water cool's the atmosphere by producing clouds that also reflect sunlight, thereby cooling the planet again.

There are feedback systems within feedback systems and most of the Climate Alarmists are fixated on CO2 and forget that Water vapor is by far the more important greenhouse gas and there is NOTHING that they can do to prevent water entering the atmosphere.

As for the tides, this is one of the bigger misconceptions that the Climate Alarmists make. They believe that added heat will melt the ice and that the sea level will rise ever higher, flooding low lying land. Again this is untrue. The majority of the Ice melt occurred over the past 10,000 years of the Holocene. The sea level is barely rising at all.

One of the more obvious deceptions by the IPCC, NASA and NOAA is that the tide is rising faster. It isn't. The IPCC predicted that it will be 600mm higher by the year 2100 (6mm per year). NASA on the other hand says it is rising by 3.3mm per year and used (fiddled/adjusted) Satellite data to try and prove this. The actual tidal measurements, made by observing the actual rise shows that it is going up between 1.1mm and 1.2mm per year. 

That's a big discrepancy between the wild predictions of the IPCC and the actual measured result and shows that even NASA has traded their reputation for integrity to claim funding from the green lobby. Indeed Democratic Governments deliberately de-funded anyone who did not agree with Climate Change Alarmism. So naturally NASA joined their group to keep the funding coming in.

In the first IPCC reports, they claimed that there would be hundreds of millions of refugees from Climate Change due to rising sea water. In fact - the opposite has been seen 30 years on. The nations that the IPCC named as being most at risk have increased their populations massively and are using fossil fuels to develop their land and even prevent any flooding. 

The sea level will keep rising, but it will be very slow and we can adapt to it. One of the biggest tells of the deception over Sea-Level rises is that both Obama and Al Gore have bought multi-million dollar homes by beaches. If they were so worried about sea-level rises - why would they buy mansions by the sea?!

@Robert C. Christian nobody is claiming that global warming isn't a thing. Did you not hear dan mention that the climate was 2 degrees hotter 25,000 years ago? What we're arguing is that it's not driven by man- that it's a natural cycle and that our contribution is very small and of little relevance in the grand scheme of things. Also if you study the vostok ice records they clearly show that C02 lags behind temperature by 200 years meaning that C02 doesn't drive temperature, temperatures changes first and C02 follows. This is because over half the worlds C02 is stored in the ocean and when temperatures increase due to solar activity the sun heats up the oceans causing a thermal expansion of the ocean which causes the ocean to release excess C02 back in to the atmosphere. This means that we're not effecting temperature with our small contributions of C02. In fact C02 only makes up 1% of the greenhouse effect, water vapour has a lot more influence on the greenhouse effect than C02 does.

Nasa:
Venus may have had a shallow liquid-water ocean and habitable surface temperatures for up to 2 billion years of its early history, according to computer modeling of the planet‚Äôs ancient climate by scientists at NASA‚Äôs Goddard Institute for Space Studies (GISS) in New York.

The findings, published this week in the journal Geophysical Research Letters, were obtained with a model similar to the type used to predict future climate change on Earth.

*Scientists long have theorized that Venus formed out of ingredients similar to Earth‚Äôs, but followed a different evolutionary path. Measurements by NASA‚Äôs Pioneer mission to Venus in the 1980s first suggested Venus originally may have had an ocean. However, Venus is closer to the sun than Earth and receives far more sunlight. As a result, the planet‚Äôs early ocean evaporated, water-vapor molecules were broken apart by ultraviolet radiation, and hydrogen escaped to space. With no water left on the surface, carbon dioxide built up in the atmosphere, leading to a so-called runaway greenhouse effect that created present conditions.*

These are not ideal changes in climate. The reason we have had a robust farming industry is because the weather has until now been very predictable, with the proper 4 seasons in a cycle, crops don't like overnight temperature swings of 68 degrees. Sure earths climate is dynamic and has its cycles but that's the issue, we are losing those well-defined cycles and entering an era of rapid weather changes with extreme swings in temperature and climate. The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.

Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century.  Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response.

Ice cores drawn from Greenland, Antarctica, and tropical mountain glaciers show that the Earth‚Äôs climate responds to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Ancient evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This ancient, or paleoclimate, evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming.

@Luke Sullivan Here's a copy and paste from another thread where I used REAL facts and supported them. 

we've been measuring the concentration of carbon in the atmosphere since the 1950's? So today scientists have actually drilled into the Arctic ice sheets to obtain samples or ice cores from many years ago containing gas bubbles which are used to measure the carbon concentration in the atmosphere from those periods. If you're familiar with the keeling curve, the evidence produced from the ice sheets actually align perfectly with the keeling curves pattern, which demonstrates an increasingly warmer climate. We have also obtained samples of sediment from the sea floor dating back to the same periods of the carbon samples extracted from the ice sheets. This sediment contains clam shells used to actually determine the temperatures from these same periods. Much like tree rings are used to indicate the age of a tree, clam shells too have layers that increase with age. Using these clam shells, they can actually measure the chemical composition, as shells incorporate oxygen from the sea water when they grow. The composition of that oxygen is determined by the temperature of the sea water, indicating the temperature during these periods. Well to put the last key data set into this puzzle to see if it correlates with the other two curves, we discover that it does! So therefore the concentration of carbon in the atmosphere is directly linked to the rising temperatures measured in the same periods that fit identically into the pattern demonstrated by the keeling curve. This is just a crash course on much of the research being done, but there's so much more. And 97% of climate scientists from all around the world have come to the same conclusions.

@mike yaeger there is so much wrong with your comment. You talk of ice cores, yet misrepresent their data claiming they somehow prove the case against AGW. I've read the literature and the data says just the opposite. They tell us of carbon concentrations dating back to 800,000 years ago. They also align with the temperatures produced in these periods with respect of the Suns activity and role in warming at the time. I never claimed the Earth hasn't been warmer. In the Cambrian, we had a sun 6 percent weaker, yet with average temperatures 18¬∞ higher, melting all the ice at both poles, sustaining terrestrial life only along the belt of the equator. Why was it warmer? Because we had concentrations of 7,000ppm at the time, warming the Earth in spite of a weaker sun that would have otherwise cooled the Earth. It is not enough to conclude climate science with silly remarks like "the climate is continueously changing, it always has," because we're aware, and that doesn't address the question as to WHY it has. And climate models have actually quite successfully reproduced temperatures dating from 1900 to present. But to your comment on the predicted ice age in the 70's, that is incorrect. A paper was published stating how we should in fact begin to cool based on orbital cycles and axial rotation resulting in a weaker sun, but the overwhelming concensus was that we were warming and would continue to do so. The ice age story was just a better headline and the media ate it up. This is now propagandas information used far too often in hopes to discredit scientific projections. Fortunately, it is easily debunked.

Yes climate cycles have happened due to natural carbon cycle, but when carbon sinks like coal and gas which have been accumulating for millennia are burned in a period of 150 years, THE RULES CHANGE. Too fast and the global ecosystem and human society cannot adapt accordingly. Anthropocentric influences have increased this rate of change; this is a scientific fact of high confidence. Thousands of scientists worldwide agree using logic not opinions. As the climate changes, there will be increased weather and ecosystem impacts to individual humans and the global economy and political systems. With regards to bankers and insurance, Dan's claims are false. Get an education in science, complex systems analysis, and critical thinking before you jump on the fallacious bandwagon of believing climate change is a hoax. For those who will dismiss this info because it doesn't align with their beliefs, lets imagine for a second climate change is a global conspiracy. First of all, lying about it is too difficult. Don't assume you know the truth to anything unless you have investigated it yourself from an unbiased lens that looks at both sides critically.

@Lohengramm I'll now respond to your greenhouse effect comment. Most of the predicted warming actually comes from water vapor, where the greenhouse effects' warming increases evaporation of the oceans and the vapor is the driving factor for further warming. The problem is while CO2's effect on the atmosphere has been well studied for decades the same cannot be said for the feedback effects like water vapor. Increased evaporation would also lead to increased cloud formation which would reflect sunlight out into space.

In any case, cold is the bigger killer than warmth. Many species would thrive in a warmer climate. Changes in global temperature disproportionately effect polar regions, so a warming climate would do more to make Canada and Siberia temperate than it would to make equatorial regions too hot.

‚ÄúBecause taboo words are shocking, they are common in situations where people want to express powerful emotions by using 'strong' language. This is called 'swearing'. When people swear, taboo words usually change their meanings completely. For example, fuck off and piss off have nothing to do with sex or urinating - they are simply violently rude ways of saying 'go away'. The strength of the original taboo word is borrowed for a different purpose. (...) None the less, students should be very careful about using taboo words and swearwords. There are two reasons for this. First of all, it is not easy to know the exact strength of these expressions in a foreign language, or to know what kind of people are shocked by them, and in what circumstances. One may easily say something that is meant as a joke, but which seriously upsets the people one is talking to. And secondly, using this sort of language generally indicates membership of a group: one most often swears in the company of people one knows well, who belong to one's own social circle, age group etc. (Children usually avoid swearing in front of adults so as not to annoy or shock them, and adults avoid swearing in front of children for similar reasons.)‚Äù  Michael Swan's Practical English Usage

Here‚Äôs how light exchange works: 
The rays of the sun hit the earth, warming it up and bounce back out to space. Compounds such as Carbon dioxide are part of the atmosphere. There is no upper limit that could actually exist on Earth that wouldn't be beneficial. As we are currently in a CO2 starved period in Earth's history, where "normal" levels are between 2000-10000 ppmv/m3, we are only now reaching 400 ppmv/m3. As atmospheric CO2 increases, the planet grows more tropical. 

We've seen as a result a 20% greening of the planet, the reemergence of high carbon-consuming conifers in the Pacific north west that went extinct/dormant because of the low, near extinction levels of atmospheric CO2 that we've lived under as a result of the last Ice Age at 170 ppmv/m3. Plants die at 140 ppmv/m3, that's how close we came to the end of all land-based life on Earth.

Even at 10000 ppmv/m3 atmospheric CO2, it remains a trace gas. There is zero correlation between global temperature and these levels of CO2 as when they were 10000 ppmv/m3, we were locked in a billion year ice age. What this suggests is that Natural Forcing is on a magnitude greater than Anthropogenic Forcing, to a degree that the planet will cool/heat up regardless of whether mankind were to have ever existed. We do not drive climate, and have no discernable impact on its natural variability.

On top of this the rate of Ocean Expansion has actually slowed since the end of the last Ice Age. One need only go back 10000 years to the end of that brutal cold period and observe 400 feet of ocean expansion that lasted until about 1000 years ago, after which its now a mere 1-3 millimeters per year. The ocean would continue to expand 1-3 millimeters per year even were we to completely eliminate all sources of Anthropogenic CO2 because we have emerged from an Ice Age, and natural forcing is/will continue to slowly warm the planet, which is causing the miniscule ocean expansion that we observe today. 

Our responsibility is to learn how to most efficiently adapt to a constantly changing environment beyond our control. Its voodoo raindancing to believe that we can control the climate (literally a form of delusion).

@Grant Page Actually, there is no upper limit that could actually exist on Earth that wouldn't be beneficial. As we are currently in a CO2 starved period in Earth's history, where "normal" levels are between 2000-10000 ppmv/m2, we are only now reaching 400 ppmv/m2. As atmospheric CO2 increases, the planet grows more tropical. We've seen as a result a 20% greening of the planet, the reemergence of high carbon-consuming conifers in the Pacific north west that went extinct/dormant because of the low, near extinction levels of atmospheric CO2 that we've lived under as a result of the last Ice Age at 170 ppmv/m2. Plants die at 140 ppmv/m2, that's how close we came to the end of all land-based life on Earth.

"The current warming trend is of particular significance because most of it is extremely likely (greater than 95 percent probability) to be the result of human activity since the mid-20th century and proceeding at a rate that is unprecedented over decades to millennia.1

Things he said in this video that aren't true:
Antarctica is on a mountain top: No, it's an entire continent.

The world temperature increased by 2 degrees thousands of years ago and is cyclical, therefore global warming is a fraud - Yes, these temperature increases are cyclical, but that's not the point. Climate change isn't the fact that the world is getting warmer again, it's the fact that this time, it's irreversible. With all the CO2 and other greenhouse gases that we are pumping into the atmosphere (which by the way was not the case thousands of years ago), the temperature will go up, but never come down, unlike the cyclical nature of earth's natural changes in temperature.

In the footnotes of contracts for beachfront properties, they never mention the risk of climate change - first of all, that is the wrong way to look at it. Contracts don't dictate climate change, climate change dictates contracts. Also, economics in this sense is all about the short term gain (25 or so years). While predictions say the sea level will rise by an amount that is sufficient enough to drown these properties, it will be more economically sound for people to invest in both beach properties then find ways to stop properties from drowning (high sea walls and other methods) than to not invest in beach properties in the first place. Banks care about money, not the environment.

Edit: he also said the earth is about 13.5 billion years old. False. That's the age of the universe.

Hey, that guy's right. The expert he spoke to in Antarctica was talking about Dansgaard - Oeschger Events. These are a phenomena in which global CO2 and temperatures have risen and fallen in a constant pattern of high and low peaks and troughs during the last glacial period, and even further back into the Holocene period. Antarctic and Greenland Ice Core data gathered from 2.6 million years of glaciological layers is solid, undeniable, unequivocal evidence that the Earth's climate and temperatures rise and fall naturally, cyclically, and regularly, without our help. What's more, the data suggests that at the end of each warming period, there is a significant spike in temperature of between 5 and 8 degrees globally that OCCURS OVER JUST SEVERAL DECADES just before the fall into another cold snap. A bit like what is happening right now. Which just so happens to coincide with our current position within the Dansgaard - Oeschger Event cycle. Science is not just fun, it's always consistent - you won't find science changing it's brand name from Global Warming to Climate Change when it decides to contradict the agenda.

Earth-orbiting satellites and other technological advances have enabled scientists to see the big picture, collecting many different types of information about our planet and its climate on a global scale. This body of data, collected over many years, reveals the signals of a changing climate.

The heat-trapping nature of carbon dioxide and other gases was demonstrated in the mid-19th century.2 Their ability to affect the transfer of infrared energy through the atmosphere is the scientific basis of many instruments flown by NASA. There is no question that increased levels of greenhouse gases must cause the Earth to warm in response.

Ice cores drawn from Greenland, Antarctica, and tropical mountain glaciers show that the Earth‚Äôs climate responds to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Ancient evidence can also be found in tree rings, ocean sediments, coral reefs, and layers of sedimentary rocks. This ancient, or paleoclimate, evidence reveals that current warming is occurring roughly ten times faster than the average rate of ice-age-recovery warming.

The global temperature increase brings disastrous consequences, endangering the survival of the Earth‚Äôs flora and fauna, including human beings. The worst climate change impacts include the melting of the ice mass at the poles, which in turn causes rising sea level, producing flooding and threatening coastal environments through which small island states risk disappearing entirely.

Climate change also increases the appearance of more violent weather phenomena, drought, fires, the death of animal and plant species, flooding from rivers and lakes, the creation of climate refugees and destruction of the food chain and economic resources, especially in developing countries.

@Captain America global warming increases the frequency of severe weather events i.e. droughts as well as blizzards. The precise reason why i.e. the science is explained and available everywhere including Wikipedia. Look it up - that way you don't have to figure out "science stuff" all on your own.

@Captain America Its called carbon dating ice core samples. They go back millions of years.  Its how we know when the ice ages happened, what compounds were in the atmosphere at the time, and their concentrations. Besides, whatever happens in your particular part of the world over the 22 years of a 4.5 billion year old planet is fairly irrelevant to the timescale that climate change normally occurs. Thermometers don't lie, globally the Earth is getting warmer, including winters. A warmer planet means higher humidity and more snow in certain parts of the world, so winters may feel more severe or extreme.

@tanmoy313 Yes, and a president who doesn't even know the difference between weather and climate certainly isn't helping. It can be confusing. Depending on where in the world you live warming might well bring increased humidity and more rain. Some people might see rain as a sign the world isn't getting warmer, but thats just not scientifically accurate at all. As the air warms glaciers and lakes lose mass to evaporation, putting more moisture into the atmosphere, and thus more rain. And depending on whether its an El Nino or El Nina year severe winters will become more common because more moisture will also mean more snow in winter. Again people will see a harsh winter as a sign climate change isn't happening. Eventually though once the ice has melted from the poles and glaciers it will completely change again and the Earth will go from the ideal conditions for life, to a period of very warm and humid conditions, and finally hot and dry as the oceans will literally boil off. This happens naturally over billions of years, the real questions is what does throwing all human activity into the mix do to the equation? If we could stop Earth from becoming Venus wouldn't we want to at least try? And the crazy thing is we have the technology, people are just lost. Exploring Human Impact On Climate Evolution

There is clear motivation to continue society's use of fossil fuels. They are the most readily commoditized of  all available fuel sources. The energy density packed into hydrocarbon molecules fueled the advance of industrial age, to which we are all indebted. The relatively few channels through which we can access these fuels has created tremendous ability to shape all aspects of any market, be it free or highly regulated OR DICTATED.
        What then, motivates the alleged scientific gathering of data to suggest that while the earth's climate is in regular flux, our use of natural resources has caused some kind of "unnatural" climate shift? We are nature, we are g-d. The earth is our gift to cherish or exploit as we see fit. And so, I personally conclude that most scientific explorations pertaining to the subject of climate chance are genuine efforts to help ensure a habitable earth for future generations.
       Everyone is wrong at some point and to some degree. The arguments against the potential for climate change seem to rely on meaningless, contrived comparisons and general dismissal. If scientists simply dismissed these rebuttals to their hypotheses we would not have any reason to take this matter seriously. The continuing and transparent work of science to strengthen its claims encourages the ongoing debate by adding new information to the pool of consideration. The FACTS are though, that whether or not fossil fuels exacerbate climate evolution, they take an enormous toll on the ecosystems that they come into contact with by changing the chemistry and topography of water and land more quickly than most life can adapt. Not to mention, the recovery of naturally sequestered hydrocarbons is the leading cause for land disputes among individuals, communities, and even governments.
       The extreme  defensive posture assumed by hydrocarbon fanatics eludes to the coordinated effort from the hydrocarbon industry to protect their market share. The campaign to discredit potential dangers of hydrocarbon exploitation dates back almost to the birth of the industry. Fossil fuel necessity is then, quite naturally reinforced by our current dependence on fossil fuels to maintain our modern lifestyle.  
          WE ARE MASTERS OF THIS EARTH. THERE IS NOTHING TO FEAR FROM OUR EXPLORING SOMETHING ''NEW''. No reasonable person expects hydrocarbons to immediately, or ever, become outlawed. There will likely always be sectors that rely on mined hydrocarbons for a variety of reasons. What is being suggested (by rational scientists) is that we as a species would very likely find it to be in our collective interest to diversify our energy portfolio to include systems that reduce the need for energy as they increase our ability to produce it anywhere, by individuals and municipalities alike. 
           I hope that really struck a nerve with everyone on both sides of this debate. It boils down to a dramatic shift in the balance of "power". Power to sustain, to produce, and to govern. That is why the hydrocarbon side of this debate is so acutely organized in their methods of planting doubt, by mis-aligning comparisons to reinforce any ideologies they deem beneficial to maintaining their market dominance. The balance of power is literally at stake. 
           Please remember, I think we are all as good as we can be, doing what we think will ensure a bright future. The only people who would demonize  each other for adhering to their respective beliefs cannot envision change and are looking to shore up the flimsy ground they themselves stand on. No one is bad for benefiting from/enjoying our current hydrocarbon exploitation, but to shirk responsibly for ensuring a productive earth for as long as possible is in my opinion inexcusable. Everyone is as much a part of the perceived problem as they are the perceived solution. Who wants tea?
             Best advice ever, because I like you, there is more to gain from an unbiased understanding of world history than a subjective interpretation of current events.

For people who don't believe in climate change and genuinely want to learn more about it:
Climate change is real, the measurements are accurate, the theory is extensively peer-reviewed, and it is caused by humans.
People often say that CO2 levels ebb and flow throughout geologic time, which is true. However, they normally change between a range of 275 and 250 ppm (parts per million). The last time CO2 was above 300 ppm in the atmosphere was approximately 34 million years ago. You could say this is just a normal ebb and flow, but this event was due to intense volcanism and took tens of millions of years to achieve. Currently, there is about 410 ppm of C02 in the atmosphere, about 1.5x the normal amount. This seems like not a lot, but any change in CO2 levels can have massive impacts on the environment. Not to mention, this change occurred in a poultry 250 years, which is far, far shorter than the millions of years it took for the last dramatic increase in CO2 levels. This amount of CO2 in the atmosphere is completely unprecedented before humans became dominant, and the increase began right as the industrial revolution took place. While CO2 levels are cyclical, they shift at an incredibly slow rate, giving organisms a chance to adapt to the warmer and cooler temperatures. At this point, with all of the obvious correlations and peer-reviewed studies, denying climate change is like denying the force of gravity or the existence of the moon.

When you are dealing with a cycle that is more than a dozen millennia long (something like  140,000 years, based upon the Vostok Ice Core data), basing any kind of projection on just a century or two of data is grossly unscientific. The "noise" perturbations in the data often last several centuries and represent rapid rise and fall of global temperatures. The sampling rate that has been used to defend the premise that there is a Human impact is woefully insignificant. To make any reasonable projections, one must consider data that goes back many thousands of years, not just to the 19th Century, AD.

And despite the repeated assertions of the climate alarmists, MOST knowledgeable, qualified scientists do NOT agree with the anthropogenic climate change hypothesis.

+Mr Roach I urge you to consider that Chesapeake Bay does not represent what's happening globally. Its not fake news, or a hoax. I live in Western Canada and our climate has changed a lot in my 50 years. Now I personally cant prove why, all I know is in the past decade we have seen a massive rise in forest fires and particularly their intensity. We now know that pine beetles which moved north as our winters have warmed, are contributing to this by killing the trees so they dry out making them extremely combustible. So now for about 3 weeks every summer our clean Canadian air is filled with thick smoke. We had air quality worse than Beijing for a while. Rather than sound the alarm the media, here and in the US, just calls it the new normal. It keeps getting worse each year so if this is the new normal we should be expecting apocalyptic fire seasons lasting 3-4 months in the near future. Remember the Ozone Hole in the 70's? Man made CFC's were proven to be the culprit and the entire planet banded together to ban CFC's. Now 40's years later the hole has been closing ever since. The ozone layer protects us from the suns ultraviolet radiation, without it most life would be dead in a matter of days. It is probably the most scientifically documented example of how we changed the makeup of our stratosphere not once but twice, the second time for good when we banned CFC's. Look around you, the oceans are full of garbage, think of how massive they are. How can you really think we could not do something like affect the climate? And why do have so much anger, at your age especially, towards a movement that is just trying to do a good thing and protect our childrens right to a future with clean air and water? Im curious, what is it that you, personally, have to lose that makes you so hostile toward this? Electric motors are just better, thats why we don't have gas engines strapped to our TVs, Toasters and Hair Dryers. The shortfall is on the storage side, but this is not the fault of the electric motor, and batteries are getting better and better every year. The future is electric, and in the next 5 years we are told we will have emission free fusion, which along with hydrogen and renewable energy where applicable, will be our future sources of power generation.Times change man, now is the time of electrification. I don't recall a revolution by the makers of the steam engine when the internal combustion engine came along.

Over a hundred years of using fossil fuels has resulted in an enormous amount of excess CO2 in the atmosphere and oceans. CO2 does not go away quickly naturally, it takes tens of thousands of years.

In the oceans, it is causing acidification and threatening the food chain. In the atmosphere is is causing global warming. The warming is causing ice melt at the poles and mountains, and warming the north pole more than the equator. The temperature difference between the poles and the equator has caused to jet streams to meander. The meandering jet streams is causing weather systems to be changed. The heated oceans are putting more water into the air.

The result is that we are experiencing extreme weather events, and patterns. We are getting droughts and floods. The droughts are causing an increase in wildfires, and the actual elimination of previously forested areas. The warming poles are causing ice melt that is raising sea levels. These disruptive events are already well underway, and essentially unstoppable without a massive change in how civilization operates.

What is required is the total elimination of fossil fuel use. But that will not be enough. In addition, the excess CO2 must be removed from the atmosphere and oceans to bring the more benign weather back. That can't happen quickly. The only quick action would be the collapse of fossil fuel using civilization. But, then the excess CO2 would not be removed at all.

So, it is well past the time for a non-punishing solution. We have abused the Earth, and now the Earth will abuse us. The best we can do is to make a total transformation to our energy use, reduction in wasteful consumption, and investment in our natural ecosystem. We cannot ignore the laws of nature and live.

On the other hand, if we work with nature, we will have a bright future.

People have to realize that global warming isn‚Äôt just a sea level thing. There are very many other problems which global warming creates.

 It produces more evaporation in the seas, which in turn produces crazier weather, like the huge ass hurricanes which battered the southern U.S. and Puerto Rico. Other crazy weather events such as tornadoes, flash floods, and incredibly hot temperatures will also inevitably be present.

While the Earth may have been 2 degrees warmer 50,000+ years ago, it has had that much time to cool to the temperatures which were seen around 100 years ago. In other words, wildlife had time to adapt. If we warm 2 degrees in 200 years versus 50,000, there will be enormous consequences to both flora and fauna. Arctic species will die in the warmth, coral reefs will boil and bleach, insects such as ticks and mosquitoes will have longer summers in which to breed, and become more numerous. 

Don‚Äôt deny that humans are causing the climate to warm at an extreme and damaging rate. I would rather see Climate Change proved a complete hoax after intense preparation for it, than it increase exponentially and cause major catastrophe. We‚Äôre much better off safe than sorry. 

And who knows, convincing ourselves to use  renewable fuel or majorly conserve resources might just be a good idea.

I am 57 years old. I grew up in Ottawa, Canada until I was 34 years old. I remember well what the weather was like there. Cold winters of -30 to -35 Celsius and hot short summers of 30+ Celsius. Ottawa is the home of Canada's longest rink, the Rideau Canal which stays open 4 to 5 months of the year.
At 34 I moved to Vancouver and lived there for 18 years. I then went back to Ottawa for 2 years. That convinced me that Global Warming is indeed real.
The weather in Ottawa has changed. It is now warmer than it ever was before. The coldest it got during the winter was -22 Celsius. We even had winter heatwaves where you could go outside in your shorts and t-shirts. The Rideau Canal was open for skating for just 18 days. That is an insane change.
When I was young, you would hear of the natural disasters from time to time but they rarely happened. You might hear of 1 or 2 a year. Now we get them every day.
So if the scientists are scamming us then it is a damn good scam.

The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine put out a video that illustrates most of the hundreds of lines-of-evidence that explain why 97% of climate scientists agree that climate change is real and caused by humans. You can see that here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gIUN5ziSfNc. If you are at all open-minded and just want to know what the truth is, I recommend it. I'd also recommend watching Before the Flood (http://watchdocumentaries.com/before-the-flood/) and Six Degrees Could Change the World (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_pb1G2wIoA). Both are free to watch. Before the Flood can be found via a Google search. Please just watch them with an open mind. If you are still convinced it's a hoax or natural, that's fine. There is nothing wrong with being skeptical, as long as you are willing to try to know the truth.

I was skeptical, as well. I thought I had all sorts of logical arguments about why global warming was natural. It was warmer in the past. We are at the end of an ice age. Trees will soak up CO2. I have a degree in engineering, and I‚Äôve taken several meteorology classes. I thought that meant I had enough of a scientific background to know that my logic made sense that climate change was natural.  I no longer believe that. The logic I used was terribly flawed. It's a complex and somewhat abstract problem. It's easy to laugh away the evidence and assume it's natural.

I not only believe humans are causing global warming; I believe the threat is far worse than I ever knew. The logic that you see from Dan Pena in this video is basically that the banks are investing in Florida beachfront condos; therefore global warming is not a threat. Mr. Pena, the banks invested in bad mortgage loans right up to the day of the 2007-2008 financial crisis that they created. What do the banks know about climate change? They weren't even able to see evidence about bad loans, which is a field they should have had expertise in.

This is the type of mistake that so many people make. It's tempting to cherry pick a piece of "evidence" that fits our prior opinions and base our arguments on that evidence. Climate scientists continue to try to find flaws in their own conclusions in order to make their understanding of nature better. People like Dana Pena do the opposite. They grab any argument they can to convince people that everything that science has discovered is wrong or fraudulent. It's not about wanting to know the truth to them. It's about not wanting to be wrong. It's a profund difference.

We are talking about a threat that may kill hundreds of millions of people in the next century. Your children and grandchildren are going to feel the very real effects of this. This is not about polar bears or eroding coastlines. This is far worse than that. When we begin to kill off critical parts of food chains, we will see suffering and starvation in many species, including humans. If you are not even willing to accept you may be wrong, you are essentially betting the lives of your grandchildren that this is not happening. You are assuming that adding billions of tons of CO2 to the carbon cycle has no effect on climate.

Is this a big hoax? Ask yourself who has the motivation to deceive the public about climate change. Climate scientists who may earn a modest, middle-class income, or oil companies who stand to lose billions of dollars if the status quo is changed? I understand the skepticism, but there must come a point when we stop letting people like Dan Pena deceive us. He really is putting the lives of your children and grandchildren at risk.

Man of the north you realize that 100% of all creatures die? However, many baby animals starve or are eaten by predators before they can grow up. So they die first. But, some of them make it to maturity and are able to find mates and have babies. Some of these animals live longer and have more babies then others. Using simple math you can figure whatever physical and mental traits that the animals had who had the most babies will be passed to the most children. That means that if there is a trait that helped a species live longer, like a giraffe being able to reach higher leaves, thus giving it access to food that others couldn't eat, will help that individual animal to live longer and possibly have more babies. Say the giraffe has 5 babies in its life and then dies. It's children will have some differences. Some faster or slower, shorter or taller. The children with the best suited traits will reproduce with others of similar traits, and so over time a species will slowly change to match it's environment.

Accountants are being required to disclose a risk to a company or maybe a REIT from climate change if the effects of global warming exist at the time of the Balance Sheet date, warming is imminent (within one year of the Balance Sheet date), and finally warming can be measured and the risk can be estimated as to the harm it will do to the property investment. Al Clark -> You have a point, but this layer still has a large volume. The surface of the earth is very large and volume still = surface area x height. Volcanoes and other natural processes have a much larger effect on this layer than human activity. The earth adapts to this activity by adjusting factors like cloud cover and rainfall. The earth has been here six billion years and has survived meteor bombardment, glaciers, and huge volcanic explosions (look up Toba - it nearly wiped out humanity and many other species).

Al Clark -> I know how to think. You should try it sometime. By your attitude, I'd guess that you've gone to a college run by a bunch of Leftist lunatics that filled you with delusions of adequacy and made you feel good about it. You probably went there long enough to accumulate a mountain of debt and no job skills. All you have to do is look at the history of the earth. All you need to know is that the earth had no ice up until 30 million years ago.  The earth had no permanent ice at the poles until the beginning of the Pleistocene era starting 2.5 million years ago.  Since then, glaciation has been the normal state of the earth and warming periods are the exception.  Over the past 450,000 years, there have been four major glaciation periods. The last one ended about 10,000 years ago. Since then there have been short-term warming and cooling periods.  The Roman times were warmer than today. There was a major cooling period during the Middle Ages during which many villages in the Alps were destroyed by advancing glaciers. During the European Renaissance there was another warm period until the "Little Ice Age" occurred in the 17th & 18th centuries. Since then the climate has been warming. If this pattern continues, the next major climate event will be another glaciation age.

I'm going to include the points of time in the video that I have issues with; this is going to be a long comment (I will use evidence, and project absolutely no bias and no assumptions, just facts/observations). Also I'd appreciate any agreements/counters, so reply if you want. Here we go...

0:05 This is an environmental discussion, why is her first question about politics?
0:18 His response and interruption to her question is very explosive, there's no reason for heated discussions over a purely scientific (and not political) topic. 0:29 "We're changing the gas..." is a ridiculous statement, but it does not justify "No, you're full of shit, sit down." However, if you research what is happening in the environment, you'd know what she's talking about, even if she doesn't word it correctly.
0:33 Maybe this is towards the end of a presentation and tensions are already high, but both of their responses are unwarranted.

1:50 - 2:30 The statement about examining ice cores is correct. But he said, "at 275,000 years ago this was the temperature, blah blah blah." Scientists examine the amount of carbon dioxide molecules that are trapped inside the bubbles in the ice, but this method can be inaccurate because the snow layer takes a while to become solid ice deep under the top layer. This means that the gas has plenty of time to diffuse out of the snow before it becomes trapped in solid ice. Consequently, that means the gas trapped inside the ice is younger than the ice surrounding it (but that statement is not true in all places, it is only true in places that don't get snowfall very often). Another thing that is important here is that he uses the difference of 275 thousand to 55 thousand years ago to describe a tiny increase in temperature. Her question is about CO2. He doesn't answer her question, and if he knew anything about the CO2 emissions she is trying to address, then he would know that the problem began with the Industrial Revolution in the 1760s, and that he should be talking about the CO2 and not the temperature of the air. The truth is, there is a big difference in CO2 concentration in the air before and after the Industrial Revolution. Next thing: a NASA graph organized in 2011 shows that the average temperature of the world was the same as previous decades in the 1940s and 1950s, but began to increase at a much steeper angle after the 1960s. As of 2011, it was .51 C warmer on average than it was in 1940 and previous decades. Now, he is correct about the Earth's temperatures being cyclical, or rising and falling in a cycle. What he says at 2:00 is slightly misleading because he doesn't say the temp of the world 275,000 years ago before saying that 55,000 years ago the world was 2 degrees C hotter than today. If he is comparing 275k ya vs 55k ya, then that means that it took 220 thousand years to raise 2 degrees C, which is a rate of 0.0000090909 degrees C increase per year. In just 50 years, 1961- 2011, it raised .51 degrees C. That's an average of 0.01 degrees per year, which is much much faster. It's so fast in comparison that it can't possibly be natural. Yes, global temperature is cyclical, but not at the rate shown in the past 50 years. 

2:36 "It's not a fart in the wind." I don't understand this metaphor: "a fart in the wind" is supposed to dissipate quickly, meaning it has no effect. If it is not a fart in the wind, then it has a lasting impact. In other news, farts aren't super relevant to adult conversations.
2:40 Earth is not 13.8 billion years old, the universe is that old. Earth is 4.5 billion years old, and WE have not been on it for that long. The oldest cells are around 4 billion years old, modern humans are only around 200,000 years old. And civilization is only 4,000 years old.
2:45 Ok so this is the only time I'll be biased. Planet Earth isn't miserable, it's beautiful. I'm only biased because I live here.
2:57 "In 25,000 years, it's most likely not going to be a problem." There's a very large possibility that humans won't be on the planet in 25,000 years. We need to focus on the problems that we have NOW that will affect the next thousand years, not 25 thousand.

3:00 - 5:00 He sounds like he's leading up to a good rebuttal until he uses bankers as his evidence. He says if Global Warming and rising sea levels were real, bankers would not finance the expensive construction of millions of homes in coastal areas. It would make the investment "fuck all" (something a high school student would say). He believes that bankers and home building entrepreneurs care about the rising sea levels. These people know there is a demand for housing in coastal areas, to they build houses to make money. If there was no demand, they wouldn't build the houses because they would lose money. Similarly, banks only exist because of interest rates. That's the only way banks make money, if they couldn't make money off of interest, they would be giving away money out of the goodness of their hearts. That doesn't sound like something they would do. They don't care about the rising sea levels, they care about creating a booming local economy for the next decade or so. If sea levels rise, they could just take their money they made with them and leave, with or without the submerged homeowners. They don't care about the environment or the danger, they just push it away like the rest of the population.
4:16 It sounds like he is trying to make up statistics as he goes when he says "Not one single investment prospectus written since 2 thousand and... this century has alluded to global warming!" This observation leads me to distrust some of his previous statistics, which haven't sounded plausible to begin with. Who's the fraud?
4:10 , 4:24 , 4:34 -  There's no reason to get so angry, or to use that language to develop what should be, a formal and polite thesis.
4:58 "The banks of the world know it's not gonna happen." What do they know? They are trained and practiced in banking, not environmental protection/analysis.
4:42 "I'm jealous of the vice President, Gore... I'm jealous he came up with the scam before I did." Dan's jealous of the man who created a scam to make money, and that doesn't make him sound very trustworthy as a public figure. He's hurting his own cause and reputation even more than when he uses the phrase "mother fucker" every 10 to 15 seconds.

There is something important to ponder about Al Gore's "scam". He said in 2006 that we only had a decade left to save the world from global warming. That statement, in my opinion, is ridiculous. However, Al Gore stated scientific evidence that humans are affecting the Earth's natural patterns, and these effects will eventually make Earth uninhabitable if they aren't stopped. Imagine if there were no humans on Earth in 2150. I don't think that environmental emergencies will be the end of the race, but they will certainly affect us until the only thing we can do is stop all industry. In a world relying on industry, that is not something we will be able to to. We have to act now. Just because Al Gore said we had one decade doesn't mean that he is lying or scamming us. He is telling the "Inconvenient Truth" that people don't want to listen to because they are already too wrapped up in their own struggle to make money in this economy. 

Dan Pena doesn't have sufficient evidence to prove anything. He believes that people who are trained to handle money care about the environment. They don't, they just make money. The goal of society is to make money, that is the biggest struggle, and it leaves no time for us to realize that you can't make money without a planet to live on.

Most people hear about fatal car accidents and they feel sorry. But inside them, they could care less because it is not a personal problem to them. They feel like it could never happen to them. People always talk about the future of global warming as if it is still a long way off, and it'll never affect them. People always say the world will end, but I won't be here to see it. They are pushing away issues to the next generation, to the generation that may have to deal with the end of the world. But the time to act is now, and even if you don't believe global warming is real, there are plenty of issues that are results of man's industry. The power to save the world relies on each individual person who needs to break the mindsets of infallibility, invulnerability, and incapability. We can save the world if we start now. 

Thanks for reading,

CO2 is a greenhouse gas. That is it both absorbs and releases infrared photons. Once released, there is one chance in 41,253 that infrared photon will continue within one degree in the same direction. This basically gives that photon a 50/50 chance of going either up or down. Since the oceans cover about 70% of the Earth, this gives that photon about a 35% chance of hitting a body of water. Infrared photons will not penetrate the surface, instead will excite an H2O molecule causing evaporation. H2O is the primary greenhouse gas which prevents the Earth from having a climate like our moon. Consequently the more CO2 we put into the atmosphere, the more H2O gets into the atmosphere, the warmer the planet gets. This is how a 40% increase in CO2 caused a 7% increase in absolute humidity. The increase in temperature due to the increase of H2O and CO2 gases is approximately .9C at present. Because it takes a tremendous amount of time for the oceans to heat, it will take centuries for the Earth to reach temperature equilibrium. If we continue to inject CO2 into the atmosphere, that heating process will continue to accelerate.

Because of the additional infrared photons are increasing evaporation in the oceans, it is also increasing evaporation on the continents. On top of that, as the temperature rises, absolute humidity goes up, but because warmer air can hold more moisture, relative humidity will go down. That means less rain on the continents, but when it does rain, there will tend to be more cloudbursts. This correlates into more droughts, heat waves, and erosion. This is already occurring in the United States.  As the temperature increases, the Hadley cell grows in size pushing the Mexican and Sahara deserts further north moving, into Europe and central North America.  As the winds come back across the Mediterranean Sea it will cause the Sahara Desert to become lush and green again.  Unfortunately, the temperature will be too warm for human habitation.

As the atmosphere warms, the differential temperature decreases between the ocean's surface and the atmosphere, blocking the ocean from releasing its heat. That is where 93% of the additional heat is being stored. This additional heat in the oceans will not only undermine the ice caps but will allow vastly larger hurricanes to form and travel at much greater distances. The imminent threat isn't sea level rise but a future of massive storm surges. This website gives a more detailed explanation.

He already addmited that the Earth was warmer in the past and that the process is cyclical - as the Antarctic scientists told him - which is true. He failed to mention (what the scientists undoubtedly also told him) that the warm phase of the cycle that we are currently entering is occurring more rapidly than it has in the past. This is very likely caused by man-made carbon emmissions in the atmosphere produced since the industrial revolution which have exacerbated the process. The precise measurement of the human contribution to the rising sea temperatures, green house gases, melting poles can be debated, but the science shows these things ARE happening. The interglacial cycle (global warming/cooling) will proceed regardless. To dismiss this as a 'scam' is foolish.

The planet's average surface temperature has risen about 2.0 degrees Fahrenheit (1.1 degrees Celsius) since the late 19th century, a change driven largely by increased carbon dioxide and other human-made emissions into the atmosphere.5 Most of the warming occurred in the past 35 years, with 16 of the 17 warmest years on record occurring since 2001. Not only was 2016 the warmest year on record, but eight of the 12 months that make up the year ‚Äî from January through September, with the exception of June ‚Äî were the warmest on record for those respective months.
The oceans have absorbed much of this increased heat, with the top 700 meters (about 2,300 feet) of ocean showing warming of 0.302 degrees Fahrenheit since 1969.The Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets have decreased in mass. Data from NASA's Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment show Greenland lost 150 to 250 cubic kilometers (36 to 60 cubic miles) of ice per year between 2002 and 2006, while Antarctica lost about 152 cubic kilometers (36 cubic miles) of ice between 2002 and 2005.Glaciers are retreating almost everywhere around the world ‚Äî including in the Alps, Himalayas, Andes, Rockies, Alaska and Africa. Satellite observations reveal that the amount of spring snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere has decreased over the past five decades and that the snow is melting earlier. Global sea level rose about 8 inches in the last century. The rate in the last two decades, however, is nearly double that of the last century. Both the extent and thickness of Arctic sea ice has declined rapidly over the last several decades. The number of record high temperature events in the United States has been increasing, while the number of record low temperature events has been decreasing, since 1950. The U.S. has also witnessed increasing numbers of intense rainfall events.Since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution, the acidity of surface ocean waters has increased by about 30 percent. This increase is the result of humans emitting more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere and hence more being absorbed into the oceans. The amount of carbon dioxide absorbed by the upper layer of the oceans is increasing by about 2 billion tons per year.

Global Warming - Ten Talking Points 
 People with advanced science degrees, most on the government dole, claim rising CO2 in the air every year will is had its hottest year on record after the year 2000 -- most states had their hottest year in the 1930's, and some in 1998. If global warming is real, then why is it not reflected in the record highs of individual states? (Alaska and Hawaii don't have over 100 years of data needed to be included in this analysis). 
 That has not been happening, but the predictions have continued for over 30 years! 
 . Here are ten examples of how the alarmists have been wrong: 
 . 
 (1) CO2 rose from 1940 to 1976, but the average temperature fell in those years -- there was no warming! 
 . 
 (2) CO2 rose from 1998 to 2014, but the average temperature fell in those years -- there was no warming! (Accurate global weather satellite data used for 1979 to 2014). 
 . 
 (3) When raw data are smoothed to see the trend, there has been no warming in the past 18 years. (RSS weather satellite global data) 
 .
 Note: Warmists ignore accurate weather satellite data, as if they do not exist, in favor of non-global, inaccurate surface measurements with a pro-warming bias. Surface measurements are severely biased by the local warming effect of economic growth: Cement, asphalt and bricks used to build new roads, parking lots, and buildings near suburban and urban temperature stations, absorb heat during the day and release it at night -- causing nighttime warming not measured at temperature stations properly sited in a consistent environment of grass and trees. 
 . 
 In the US, properly sited temperature stations reflect half the warming measured by improperly sited stations affected by economic growth around them (aka "urban heat island effect"). 
 . 
 Over 6,000 land temperature stations were active in the mid-1960s, but over 80% of them are no longer in use today. Stations no longer in use were mainly rural, and at higher latitudes and altitudes -- dropping those stations, which tended to be in cooler locations, raises the average temperature calculations, creating a pro-global warming bias in surface data not seen in weather balloon and weather satellite data.
 . 
 Even with those pro-warming biases, the warmists' beloved surface data still show no warming trend for over 12 years! 
 . 
 (4) Warmists claim the Earth is warming year-after-year, but temperature records from US states tell a different story: 
 - Only one of the contiguous 48 US states had its hottest year on record after the year 2000 -- most states had their hottest year in the 1930's, and some in 1998. If global warming is real, then why is it not reflected in the record highs of individual states? (Alaska and Hawaii don't have over 100 years of data needed to be included in this analysis). 

 . 
 (5) Southern Hemisphere sea ice area has repeatedly set new records in 2014, which is obviously caused by global cooling in that half of Earth (satellite data first collected in 1979). 
 . 
 (6) Several recent winters have been among the coldest in centuries in the United Kingdom, and continental Europe, and the 2013-2014 winters was one of the coldest and snowiest in decades for much of the United States and Canada. 
 . 
 We've been having fewer severe storms on Earth, not more:

 (7) 2014 is near a 30-year low in worldwide hurricane energy (measured by ‚Äúaccumulated cyclone energy,‚Äù or ACE index). 
 . 
 (8) Land falling hurricanes in the US have been in a downward trend since 1945. 
 . 
 (9) It has been 3,310 days since the last Category 3 or stronger hurricane hit the US mainland (Katrina in 2005), as of November 18, 2014 -- this is the longest stretch (by more than 1,000 days) without a strong hurricane since records began in 1900.

CO2 levels rise AFTER temperature increases.  There has never been a time, in all of the known temp and CO2 data, of it happening the opposite way.  The oceans contribute the vast majority of the CO2 in our atmosphere, so as the temps rise, there's more evaporation, thus more CO2.  The single greatest predictor of our weather is the sun, thru solar activity and cosmic rays, which increase cloud cover.  During the Little Ice Age of medieval Europe, astronomers saw very few sun spots.  As the spots increase, we get warmer.  Greenland has been farmed before during one of these warm periods, in fact, warm periods have been a time of growth and plenty, for advances in civilization, it's the cold periods that are the killers.  CO2 makes up less than half of a percent of our atmosphere, humans contribute a tiny fraction of that one half percent.  This crap that CO2 is the single most important driver of our weather is just that... Crap.  Of course we should take care of the planet and try to keep it clean for future generations, but driving people out of business and jobs with regulations and taxes isn't the way to do that.  Nor is trying to force ridiculously expensive and ineffective things like solar panels on developing countries.  The climate change furor is mostly a way for scientists to get funding, it's become its own multi billion dollar industry.  Now if you want to study anything, you have to include "climate change" in your proposal to get money.  We'd be better off pouring all those funds into an effective anti asteroid or comet program, since we know they often can't detect them until they're very close, and they actually DO pose a threat to the survival of our species.  Just ask the dinosaurs.  Oh wait, you can't, they were WIPED OUT BY AN ASTEROID HIT.

Dan Pena has not provided a shred of evidence to contradict the science of global warming.

Every climate scientist, and everyone who understands climate science knows that there are cyclical contributions to climate and sea levels.

The glaciation periods are due to changes in orbital parameters. The periods of these cycles are in tens and hundreds of thousands of years. The interglacial period we are in has given relatively stable temperatures and sea levels for the last 10,000 years, during whicch agricultural regions were developed in regions where the climate was suitable and cities and other infrastructure grew up to support those regions.

Since the industrial revolution, humans have been adding CO2 to the atmosphere with the result that warming unprecedented in human history has occured and continues with a resultant change for agricultural regions and sea levels that are occuring over time spans of decades and a few centuries.

If human civilization is around in 10,000 years when the next glaciation period is due, people may well have to burn coal to raise the temperature.

As far as what the banks are or are not doing. These are the geniuses who  brought us the Great Recession. The CEO's are intersted in short term profit, which will get them their next bonus. We know that the climate has varied wildly over the planet's past, as Dan Pena points out. It should be noted that scientists do have a pretty good understanding of the mechanisms that have driven previous changes in the climate. Precession, changes in solar output, variations in the Earths orbit and tectonic activity are to name but a few. At the moment their is no scientific consensus around a natural alternative that challenges the unanimity of the man made global warming theories. In fact it is not clear if the crux of the deniers arguments are that warming is happening and that it is not man made or that it isn't happening at all. Dan Pena alludes to this contradiction. In one breath he is telling us that ice cores clearly demonstrate that the climate has changed in the past and in the next he is telling us that rich people are building condos next to the sea, suggesting that the climate isn't about to change any time soon. Which is the pertinent argument?

I was about to leave but have to add this:  If you live on or near salt water than you probably know all about tides, latitude, seasons and all that.  I owned/lived on a 5 acre section of tropical beach for years, 7.9 degrees N. Latitude, west coast of Costa Rica.  Tides rise and fall less as you approach the equator, so changes in sea levels are harder to determine.  Over the ten years I owned that land no one could ever say exactly where, the "high tide", and "low tide" marks were despite being described on the property deed.  The Brits took almost a century to figure out a system to measure tides for the same reasons, "how do you mark where the waterline is?"  They used a long wharf with a controlled area for floats that were controlled by rising tides and then collected enough data to come up with accurate enough measurements to facilitate their navigation skills.
My point is, your observations don't tell us anything.

It never ceases to amaze me how many people fall for this.  Would you go to a plumber for brain cancer or some rare, fatal disease?  Or would you go to a medical specialist who knows what the latest peer reviewed research in the field is? Even better would be would you trust a banker to disarm a bomb set to blow up the building you and every member of your family are stuck inside, or would you rather have someone who works in the field? And while some of you might point towards folks like Dr. Ivar Giaever or Dr. Freeman Dyson and their disbelief, this is like trusting a proctologist to tell you you do not have brain cancer.  Dr. Giaever specializes in solid state physics, such as is used in designing semiconductors, and later in biophysics, while Dr. Dyson is quantum electrodynamics, solid state physics, and nuclear physics, as well as having talked about some concepts in civilizations colonizing space, such as Dyson Spheres. As such, they are in effect the proctologist who decides wrongly to speak outside of their field, going up against hundreds of neuro-oncologists who have discussed your case and confirmed that you do have a rare form of brain cancer. 

In addition, you have to look for financial motives of a number of deniers.  Both Pena and Dr. Giaever benefit in the short to medium term from businesses not having to deal with regulations to start curbing AGW.  There have been a number of instances where scientists have been paid by groups and published findings which were found to be false if not outright fraudulent. You (I hope) would not trust a snake oil salesman for your cancer treatment as well...

Regarding the temperatures at SPS (or the recent temps in the eastern US), if you look at what has been published, you will see items such as the following:

1) Notes that the extreme southern polar regions will behave slightly differently than one might casually expect, because of zonal barriers similar to those seen around the tropical regions, and that the northern polar region would be far more susceptible due to the proximity of large land masses which are not permanently covered in snow/ice.
2) That there would be some areas which at various times would be cooler or wetter while others would be warmer/drier, and that it was important to look at the overall trends.

Both of these were being talked about back in the early 1980s in papers and lectures, such as those written/given by Dr. Lonnie Thompson and his wife, Ellen Mosley-Thompson at the Byrd Polar Research Center at Ohio State.

An apparent contradiction in the observed cooling behavior of Antarctica between 1966 and 2000 became part of the public debate in the global warming controversy, particularly between advocacy groups of both sides in the public arena[2] including politicians,[3] as well as the popular media. In his novel State of Fear, Michael Crichton asserted that the Antarctic data contradict global warming.[4] The few scientists who have commented on the supposed controversy state that there is no contradiction,[5] while the author of the paper whose work inspired Crichton's remarks has said that Crichton "misused" his results.[6] There is no similar controversy within the scientific community,[7] as the small observed changes in Antarctica are consistent with the small changes predicted by climate models, and because the overall trend since comprehensive observations began is now known to be one of warming. At the South Pole, where some of the strongest cooling trends were observed between the 1950s and 1990s, the mean trend is flat from 1957 through 2013.

HIs logic is fundamentally flawed, though. Banks, as proven time and time again, including only 10 years ago, are all about sharp short term gain vs long term investment. The housing bubble would never have happened if they planned long term. They are a business and hence make business decisions. If they can invest in beach front condos *now* and sell them *now*, their investment is secure as it's the condo owners that will pay the price, not the banks these condos were purchased from. To be blunt, businesses will lie to get business if no one call them out on that lie right away. That's how business works. It's an calculated gamble.

Now on the other side of that coin, you have climate scientists. There's no profit to be made in science unless you're some sort of celebrity. There's no direct profit to be made at all other than getting funding for your field of research so as to keep you in your line of work. Also, the very nature of science means it's nearly impossible to lie as their studies get peer reviewed, and other scientists looooove finding the flaws in your math, so your calculations have to be very precise. So if the *overwhelming* majority of climate scientists support the idea that man made climate change is real and happening, and have the math and chemistry to prove it beyond reasonable doubt, then it's obvious who you need to believe.

By the way, natural cycles of rising and cooling temperatures either happen over thousands of years ... or as a result of a major natural catastrophe such as a Yellowstone scale volcano erupting. But in our case, temperatures are rising by 2 or 3 degrees in less than a century, with no such epic disasters, and with only the measurable rise in greenhouse gases being a cause.

Jan 8, 2018 NASA-led study solves a methane puzzle

Methane emissions have been rising sharply since 2006. Different research teams have produced viable estimates for two known sources of the increase: emissions from the oil and gas industry, and microbial production in wet tropical environments like marshes and rice paddies. But when these estimates were added to estimates of other sources, the sum was considerably more than the observed increase. In fact, each new estimate was large enough to explain the whole increase by itself.

Scientist John Worden of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California, and colleagues focused on fires because they're also changing globally. The area burned each year decreased about 12 percent between the early 2000s and the more recent period of 2007 to 2014, according to a new study using observations by NASA's Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectrometer satellite instrument. The logical assumption would be that methane emissions from fires have decreased by about the same percentage. Using satellite measurements of methane and carbon monoxide, Worden's team found the real decrease in methane emissions was almost twice as much as that assumption would suggest.

When the research team subtracted this large decrease from the sum of all emissions, the methane budget balanced correctly, with room for both fossil fuel and wetland increases. The research is published in the journal Nature Communications.

The question to climate change deniers should be as follows: Is climate change only ever a natural event or is it possible that human activity can cause climate change? 'Climate change deniers' seem to fall into two categories. The first category is simply the one where they say climate change only ever has natural causes and the second category is where they admit that human activity can cause climate change but isn't causing climate change at the moment.

So for the first group you ask what are the natural causes for the rise in atmospheric co2. For the second group you ask if human activity contributes to a rise in atmospheric co2 and how much has that rise been. They may come up with some nonsense about sun activity and so on but this is easily debunked.

After this you present a timeline of co2 increases and talk about the effects on the environment of increased co2. Then when they point out what they think is an anomaly in the data you point out that the data is remarkably clear that over a period of a number of years co2 in the atmosphere has dramatically increased.

Biggest fraud in history? I beg to differ. I would save that moniker for fractional reserve banking, 'the Bush administration', or quantitative easing. But applying such a term to the easily observeable rise in global average temperature flies in the face of Occum's Razor. It would be very easy to manipulate one set of measurements based upon a political agenda. Or even two or three data sets. But manipulating the hundreds of data sets we now have from around the globe, across a multitude things being measured, all of which point in the same general direction? That would require a conspiracy amongst such a larhge number of people that it very quickly fails the "unneccessary multiplication of entities. "test. Or, to state it differently, it is not the simplest explanation for the data we currently have. When presented with two opposing explanations for interpretting a given collection of information, the simpler of the the two is most often the correct interpretation.

No more opinions please, only hard, scientific facts.  Climate modelling is not fact.  CO2 driving climate is not fact, it is a false assumption.  Climate directly affects CO2 levels, not the opposite, (as is claimed).  Factually, based on true scientific evidence, we are on the cusp of a period of global cooling, and any warming recently witnessed is merely a "blip" used in error as "evidence" for anthropogenic climate change.   Cloud cover is the main culprit, not water vapour and not CO2.  The fact that "global warming"  was changed in title to "climate change" ought to immediately give the game away to any moderately intelligent being.  The factors affecting our climate are way too complex to be open to direct interpretation via computer modelling.  Solar activity, cloud cover, asymmetry of the earth, cyclical phenomena all play a part and the interactions are highly complex and unpredictable.  To claim that a paltry 2% increase in CO2 levels, as caused by human activity has a catastrophic effect on climate, when that 2% is actually only 2% of the current maximum of 400 parts per million of CO2 in the entire atmosphere is simply ludicrous, as it amounts to only a 0.000008%  atmospheric increase if one properly does the maths.  To suggest that such an increase can alter climate is insane at best and criminal at worst.

I have a better explanation, even though I like Dan's. When was the thermometer invented? 1870s. When did they start recording temperatures, not just reading the ice cores, because those are only plus or minus three degrees accurate and only sample a tiny percentage of the planet. First temperature records go back to the 1930s when the thermograph was invented, based upon the tickertape machines of the stock market. Before that, nobody was recording the temperature 24/7. They might have recorded once a day, but that is worthless. And even with a thermograph, that creates huge amounts of data that usually varies by up to 30 degrees in one location. All the thermographs since the 1930s have only sampled 1% of the planet, and 40% of those have been located in the US, so the rest of the world is purely a guess. Nobody recorded the temperatures of the oceans until two years ago. So when did they actually start recording the global temperatures, with any degree of accuracy? Do you know? 1979 was the first satellite that sensed that. So guess what, we have a sum total of 39 years of accurate¬† temperature records. Everything else is just¬†a guess, and the degree of accuracy of the other data is again, plus or minus two to three degrees. So how much has the temperature changed since 1979? Do you really know? What does the raw data show? Nothing, it shows nothing, absolutely zero change, in the last 39 years. Only by manipulating the data can you show any change. So what the fuck are they talking about? Sure, I believe the climate changes, but we know nothing, we have no clue why, and only after spending $20B a year for thirty years now do we know that it is definitely not CO2. Oh, BTW, the sea level has not risen even a tenth of an inch since we have been measuring it. All the changes have been solely because of the natural rise and fall of the land, like Miami. The parts of Miami and Boston getting higher sea levels are the parts built on swamp land. The land is sinking, naturally. We need to put Al Gore against a wall and shoot that asshole.
