Bo Rood this comment shows you deeply misunderstand thr theory of evolution. The 'unit' of evolution is not the organism, as you assume, but the gene. Thinking from the gene instead of the organism solves all your 'problems'. One celled organisms with genes that drive them to co√∂perate with other cells will create clusters of cells that slowly evolve to be one being. No species has ever been found in a mid-stage of evolution because it is not the organism that is slowly evolving, but its genes, and a change in genes does not always constitute a change in fenotype. Also don't forget that evolution is a painstakingly long proces that relies on faulty copying of genes, something that cannot easily be demonstrated in a laboratorium (although it has been done with fruit flies, this is one of the longest experiments ever set up).

If you cannot offer an alternative theory that has the same level of empirical adequaty, you can not discard the theory of evolution. Especially not when your 'problems' are pseudo-problems that can be solved by having a proper grasp on the most current new insights concerning evolution.

The guy wearing the red tie only exceeds his foul language with his ignorance about climate issues. 
To take just his first point where he claims a scientist in Antarctica told (from ice core evidence) him "the world fifty five thousand years ago was two degrees warmer Celsius than it is today". He then went on to refer to "the 13.8 billion years we have been on this planet".
Both of those statements are false, and are easily shown to be so.
Here is the graph of Antarctic temperature and CO2 from the well known Vostok ice core:
http://www.euanmearns.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/vostok_temperature_co2.png
As you can see, the temperature in Antarctica 55,000 years ago was about 4 to 5degC COLDER than at present, which translates to about 2degC colder than at present globally (temperature changes in Antarctica are about double those of the global average).
And, of course, it is the Universe that is 13.8 billion years old, The Earth is about 4.5 billion years old, and we have only been on it for a few hundred thousand years.
Would you not think that someone who had been asked to sit on a stage and give his opinions on this subject might have checked his information instead of making a fool of himself by talking such nonsense?

There was a time, the Eemian interglacial, about 125,000 years ago when global temperatures were slightly warmer than the present, though we will exceed them this century unless we are very careful. But as a consequence of that warming spike, sea levels rose between 6 and 9 metres, and there is evidence of storms the ferocity of which is beyond our experience - they hurled boulders weighing more than a thousand tonnes well above sea level, see;
http://www.independent.co.uk/environment/megastorms-that-can-throw-thousand-tonne-boulders-up-cliffs-may-be-on-their-way-back-thanks-to-a6754511.html
The Eemian stands as a warning of what will happen if we do nothing. It is not a source of complacency for rich fools, or anyone else.

First of all, I have no interests or ties to the oil industry. I am retired with a science degree in 3D CADD, architecture and engineering. I now study science as a hobby. Global Warming is caused by the sun. It has nothing to do with the CO2 gas concentrated near the ground in our atmosphere. Let me show you the evidence.

If temperatures rise by the percentage of CO2 in the atmosphere then it would be apparent in the CO2 levels in the summer compared to the winter right? Meaning the CO2 levels in the atmosphere should be higher in the summer than in the winter, that's when it is hot out right?

Near the end of the summer, when temperatures are hot, in August, the CO2 levels in the atmosphere on average in the northern hemisphere are round 150 ppmpv. Extremely low! At the end of winter, before spring, the CO2 levels in the atmosphere on average are around 400 ppmpv. So as the Earth heats up, from spring to summer the CO2 levels in the atmosphere slowly dwindle till August when the CO2 levels are around 150 ppmpv. This is because plants absorb CO2 and use the carbon molecules for food. So at the end of summer the plants that have been growing all summer absorbed most of the CO2 from the atmosphere. 

The picture this paints is that by reducing the CO2 levels in the atmosphere causes the temperatures on our planet in the northern hemisphere to increase. But the CO2 levels increase during the winter because it is cold outside and plants go dormant, no longer using the CO2 for food. This is not evidence that CO2 is causing climate change! 

When we address the seasonal tilt of the Earth's axis in respect to the sun causes this notion of CO2 being the cause of climate change to fail miserably. When we use the sun's energy output as a variable it clearly shows us that climate change is caused by the sun, not because of humans nor because of CO2 gas concentrated near the ground in the atmosphere. No blanketing effect! No greenhouse effect, nothing!

March 5th and 6th of 2012 the sun unleashed a string solar flares, I believe around 11 of them, aimed right at Earth, the biggest one was a class X5.4 flare. The average temperature in March where I live is around 32¬∞ F. March 18th 2012 at the Traverse City Airport the temperature peaked at around 82¬∞ F. Clearly sun had everything to do with the temperature spike occurring for about 2 weeks in March of 2012! CO2 levels in the atmosphere had nothing to do with the temperature spiking like that!

Climate change is real, but it is all because of nature, not man! PEACE.

The earth radiates heat. All of the heat in the CO2 absorption spectrum is already saturated.

The 'Greenhouse' effect of increased CO2 since 1958 is approximately 1.7 W/m^2. Given the average TSI is 1361 W/m^2 ... changes in solar flux are much more likely to cause climate change than is heat flux radiated towards earth from atmospheric CO2. 

Its the sun that causes phases of warming and cooling in our climate. CO2 does not.

"But the science showing CO2 as a driving force is pretty, uh, forced."
I don't see anything forced about it. Milankovitch cycles were the trigger of temperature rises in the past and water vapor can only take you so far before it rains back down (and it absorbs different wavelength than CO2), but once the process starts, CO2 starts to drive this positive feedback. Now we are driving that positive feedback by putting extra CO2 into the natural cycle.

"Also, I think the warming, itself, probably peaked at the end of the '90s."
1998 was unusually warm El Nino year, but 2016 was even warmer El Nino year. 16 of the 17 warmest years on record have occurred since 2001.

"To me, it's like a bunch of people suddenly discovered climate change"
That may be, but to a scientific community this is over a 100 year old discovery. It just wasn't such an urgent problem 100 years ago. There is even a 60 year old educational film warning us about man made CO2 rise and climate change called 'The Unchained Goddess'.

"To me, there's a lot of questionable science going on" Yes.. creationists, flat earthers and anti-vaccers say the same thing when they are faced with science that challenges their views.. What I'm wondering is: What makes you different from them?

CO2 is one of the weakest of all greenhouse gases, for starters.  But it is tied to output of other greenhouse gases, so it makes sense to track it.  But the science showing CO2 as a driving force is pretty, uh, forced.  

My issue is mostly with the POLICIES the more hysterical amongst us are advocating. Those policies' main results seem to be to hurt the U.S., who would HONOR the agreements, while other signatories to Paris Accords, like Germany and Japan, are turning back to coal, because the price per kilowatt hour was getting too steep.

I think there are many things that can be done to reduce our footprint on Ma Earth.  But the clowns pushing Global Warming have their own agenda, it would seem.  

Also, I think the warming, itself, probably peaked at the end of the '90s.  Myself, I think much of what's going on is due to the Sun, about which we can do little.  Other planets in the solar system also seem to be showing signs of warming, due to solar activity, but you don't see any coal-fired plants on them.

To me, it's like a bunch of people suddenly discovered climate change, when a 5-yr-old could learn about it on Discovery Channel, from Dinosaur and Ice Age documentaries.  

To me, there's a lot of questionable science going on, and TERRIBLE policy coming out from those who trumpet the science the loudest.   And to oppose them on policy makes you a science-denier, which I most definitely am not.

There are number of major problems facing humanity that likely can't be solved without nature forcing those issues on us. They are:

- Many people still want to consume and love materialism;
- We, as a species, have allowed transnational corporations to become far too powerful and pervasive,
- Perhaps most importantly, there are just far too many people on the planet, probably 6 billion too many. During the first 150 years of the industrial revolution, the CO2 present in the atmosphere increased by just under 15ppm. We now see increases of 15ppm every 5 years.

For example, from 1800 to 1900 world population increased by 600 million with an increase of 10 ppm CO2. In the last 27 years alone, world population has increased by 2.3 billion and ppm CO2 has increased by over 50. The correlation between rising ppm CO2 levels and population growth is absolutely incontrovertible.

The question is about what. There are several layers to the question. 
It is provable that CO2 absorbed two narrow bands of IR strongly.
BUT:
Do those bands actually cause significant greenhouse effect? Or are factors, such as humidity the primary cause?

does some CO2 induced warming cause large positive feedbacks?

are there negative feedbacks?

What drove temperature changes before human contribution, and can that be accurately be accounted for in the current data set?

Can computer models accurately simulate chaotic systems?

If warming does cause damages, is the damage from returning to a pre-industrial life worse than the damage cause from warming?

Most "skeptics" are with what science has been able to prove, the debate is over what has not been proven and falsified repeatedly while still being trotted around in media.
